(Naked Security, 20 June 2013) <http: 06=\"\" 12=\"\" 2013=\"\" microsoft-citadel-takedown=\"\" nakedsecurity.sophos.com=\"\"></http:> accessed 1 July 2022.\n Zeitlin (n 72) 753–54.\n Plohmann, Gerhards-Padilla, and Leder (n 11) Botnets: Measurement, Detection, Disinfection and Defence 89–90.\n ibid. 115–16.\n ibid, 114.\n David Dittrich, Felix Leder &amp; Tillmann Werner, 'A Case Study in Ethical Decision Making Regarding Remote Mitigation of Botnets' in Radu Sion and others (eds) Financial Cryptography and Data Security FC 2010 Workshops, WLC, RLCPS, and WECSR, Tenerife, Canary Islands, Spain, 25–28 January, 2010, Revised Selected Papers (Springer Link, 2010) 216–30.\n Draft Articles on Prevention of Transboundary Harm Article 3.\n Plohmann, Gerhards-Padilla, and Leder (n 11) Botnets: Measurement, Detection, Disinfection and Defence 123–24.</https:></https:>\nABHIJEET SHRIVASTAVA AND RUDRAKSH LAKRA\nalso creating deterrence against such cybercrime. Finally, any financial or similar incentives that may have motivated the creation of the Botnets should be targeted, since even if the Botmasters are not arrested, there would be little reason to rebuild the Botnet absent such motives.\nAgain, capacity differentials would determine whether these measures are obligatory on a State or mere suggestions. Yet one commonality across all is the need for international co-operation in their success—cyber capabilities can only flourish best with collective efforts; arrests and prosecutions of transnational cybercriminals can only concretize with mutual legal assistance; and the social evils enabling Botnets eradicated with concerted diplomatic initiatives. It seems then, that due diligence is not only a gap-filling legal arsenal against Botnets amidst the presently mutually suspicious State relations in cyberspace; instead, due diligence must also be viewed as a norm that can realize its maximal potential only in a milieu where States develop robust co-operative and consultative efforts. In that vein, it may well become a vehicle for facilitating internationalism in cyberspace, in line with its core logic. This brings us to the final Section of this article, where we detail the overarching obligation of all States toward cyber capacity building, as also the role of international co-operation in its fruition.\n# THE OBLIGATION TOWARD CYBER CAPACITY BUILDING\nAs previously discussed in Factors affecting standard of conduct and The state of origin's knowledge, the obligation of due diligence is a 'duty of conduct'; yet that carries within it an obligation which is a 'duty of result.' This obligation is to build a 'minimum' institutional capacity that would allow States to effectively carry out their due diligence obligations. This framework should equip the State to be able to detect potential significant harm and to take appropriate mitigating measures to minimize and prevent the harm. This aspect of due diligence has been recognized by the ILC and ICJ. For capacity building, States should make reasonable efforts to create an ability to detect risk, and the capability to mitigate and halt that risk. This obligation of result is necessary for the due diligence norms to have any bite. States including South Korea, Canada, the United Kingdom and Australia in their report on incorporating UNGGE non-binding norms have focused on the building of institutional capacity. These have included raising awareness, creating an appropriate legislative framework, creating or strengthening departments for countering cyber threats, developing incident response plans and domestic policy, and enabling cooperative partnerships—both domestic and international. As with other due diligence obligations, the minimum baseline that is expected of States would differ based\n ibid 121.\n Ahmad (n 71) Why Botnets Persist: Designing Effective Technical and Policy Interventions, 29–31.\n Supra Section on Impact Assessment Obligations Around Botnets\n Fausto Pocar, 'New Challenges for International Rules Against Cyber-Crime' (2004) 10 European Journal on Criminal Policy and Research 27.\n Ney and Zimmermann (n 18) Cyber-Security beyond the Military Perspective: International Law, Cyberspace, and the Concept of Due Diligence.\n Coco, and de Souza Dias (n 20) 'Cyber Due Diligence': A Patchwork of Protective Obligations in International Law, 788; Russel Buchan, 'Cyberspace, Non-State Actors and the Obligation to Prevent Transboundary Harm' (2019) 21 Journal of Conflict &amp; Security Law (2016) 429, 434–439.\n ibid; ILC, Draft Articles on Prevention Article 3 [15]–[17]; Couzigou (n 62) Securing cyber space: the obligation of States to prevent harmful international cyber operations 50–51.\n Draft Articles on Prevention of Transboundary Harm Article 3 [14]–[17], Article 5.\n Pulp Mills [197].\n Andraz Kastelic, \"Due Diligence in Cyberspace: Normative Expectations of Reciprocal Protection of International Legal Rights\" (UNIDIR, 2021) <https: due-diligence-cyberspace-normative-expectations-reciprocal-protection-international=\"\" publication=\"\" www.unidir.org=\"\"> accessed 1 June 2022, 10.\n ibid.</https:>\nREVISITING DUE DILIGENCE IN CYBERSPACE\n\nThis Section attempts to provide indicators which States can follow for the process of establishing the capability to detect contemporary Botnets and conduct mitigation efforts. Such indicators would also serve to illustrate the conduct expected from States as technologies and Botnet threats evolve. Further, States are free to design their institutional baseline as long as it is adequate for the harm in question. While being mindful of capacity differentials of States, we divide these baseline measures into six categories: national/sectoral cybersecurity strategies, legal measures, measures focusing on preventing Botnet infection, on early detection of botnets, collaborative measures, and review-related measures.\n## National/Sectoral cybersecurity strategies\nStates have limited resources and regulatory capacities. Due diligence recognizes this central pillar of policymaking and accordingly, it requires states to use their best efforts based on their capabilities. To allocate their resources and the regulatory capacity in an economically efficient manner, States should create a strategy for countering threats akin to Botnets based on a risk-based approach, which would help the State identify threats and security gaps that pose a high risk and those that pose a low risk. Based on this level of risk assessment, the State can focus its resources on priority areas where high-risk vulnerabilities exist. This process can be and should ideally be performed both nationally and sectorally.\nNational cybersecurity strategies should become the cornerstone that guides State measures and initiatives. Special focus should be on strengthening and making their networks more resilient to support critical infrastructure, critical supply chains and major financial institutions. Such a National Cybersecurity strategy can also be developed based on a multi-stakeholder approach as recommended by the International Telecommunication Union (ITU). As regards feasibility, the most States should be able to draw up these strategies as it only requires states to take stock of their resources, their regulatory capacity and the landscape of threats faced by them. Indeed, as of 2020, the ITU found that 127 countries out of 194 countries have now adopted a National Cyber Strategy.\n## Legal measures\nA suitable legal and regulatory framework is the bedrock of due diligence. As the ILC in their Draft Articles on Transboundary Harm notes, “[s]tates concerned shall take the necessary legislative, administrative or other action…”. The legal framework should lay out relevant rights\n Draft Articles on Prevention of Transboundary Harm Article 3 [12]–[13] 17; Coco, and de Souza Dias (n 20) Cyber Due Diligence: A Patchwork of Protective Obligations in International Law 787-88; Buchan (n 20) Cyberspace, Non-State Actors and the Obligation to Prevent Transboundary Harm 443; Bannelier-Christakis (n 20) Cyber Diligence: A Low-Intensity Due Diligence Principle for Low-Intensity Cyber Operations? 37; Couzigou (n 62) Securing cyber space: the obligation of States to prevent harmful international cyber operations 47.\n Draft Articles on Prevention of Transboundary Harm Article 3 [11].\n Coco, and de Souza Dias (n 20) Cyber Due Diligence: A Patchwork of Protective Obligations in International Law, 787-88.\n OECD, OECD Regulatory Policy Outlook 2021: Risk-based regulation (OECD Publishing, 2021).\n Draft Articles on Prevention of Transboundary Harm Article 3 [3], [5].\n ITU, 'ITU Botnet Mitigation Toolkit' (Jan 2008) ITU Telecommunication Development Sector <https: cyp=\"\" itub-cyb=\"\" cyp/ecybersecurity=\"\" docs=\"\" itu-botnet-mitigation-toolkit-background.pdf=\"\" www.itu.int=\"\"> accessed 1 July 2022, 25; Shackelford, Russell and Kuehn (n 84) Unpacking the International Law on Cybersecurity Due Diligence: Lessons from the Public and Private Sectors 34-42.\n Coco, and de Souza Dias (n 30) Cyber due diligence in international law 187-190.\n ITU (n 176) Global Cybersecurity Index 2020 145-47; ITU (n 243) Botnet Mitigation Toolkit 25.\n ibid.\n ibid.\n ibid.\n Draft Articles on Prevention of Transboundary Harm Article 5.</https:>\nABHIJEET SHRIVASTAVA AND RUDRAKSH LAKRA\nand responsibilities clearly for State and private parties, and the sanctions and remedies in case of a breach. Such a framework would provide foresight to those subject to it and promote deterrence. In connection to Botnets, any legal framework should attempt to meet two objectives: first, it should clearly criminalize the operation of a Botnet and second, it should provide tools to law enforcement, and other State bodies to effectively investigate and take enforcement actions against Botnets. Attempts at facilitating such legal frameworks can take guidance from prevailing international and regional standards.\nTurning first to criminalization, the criminalizing law should capture the range of crimes committed by Botnets; these include both ‘core’ cybercrime and ‘cyber-enabled’ crimes. States should ensure that the definition of the crimes adopted by the law should not be such that it succumbs to obsolescence very soon with technological changes. A possible approach for this is to define cyber-criminal activities at a high level of abstraction, which would also cover crimes unforeseeable at the time. This is in line with the approach in the Budapest Convention. Further in line with the Budapest Convention and other such initiatives, it is important to push for creating a uniform and common legislative baseline framework across jurisdictions, so that Botmasters could not exploit any difference in laws in different countries. In this regard, there is presently wide disagreement between States about the precise content of crimes beyond core crimes, as presently seen in ongoing debates under the UN’s auspices around a cybercrime treaty. This disagreement limits the possibility of harmonization, and thus, one hopes that a representative consensus is reached.\nRegarding the second proposed objective for laws, as Lubin explains, using existing domestic legal remedies such as injunction orders can be inappropriate for Botnet mitigation. Thus, the law should provide remedies and procedural tools which accommodate the uniqueness of cyberspace and facilitate suitable resources tailored for Botnet mitigation. The question of which procedural tools law enforcement should have can again be resolved by drawing from international standards. There is also a need to build regulatory capacity in a manner that Botnet mitigation operations could be approved at a quicker pace and the body adjudicating these requests is well versed in the specific practical and technical details. Having a quicker turnaround period is important as Botnets are constantly evolving. Consequently, responses against them can quickly become antiquated.\n Coco, and de Souza Dias (n 30) Cyber due diligence in international law 171.\n ibid.\n Plohmann, Gerhards-Padilla, and Leder (n 11) Botnets: Measurement, Detection, Disinfection and Defence 121–22, 125, 127; ITU (n 243) Botnet Mitigation Toolkit 21–31.\n For instance see, Convention on Cybercrime (adopted 23 Nov 2001, entered into force 1 July 2004) 2296 UNTS 167; Arab Convention on Combating Information Technology Offences (adopted 21 December 2010); Arab Convention on Combating Information Technology Offences (adopted 21 Dec 2010); African Union Convention on Cyber Security and Personal Data Protection (adopted 27 June 2014); UNODC, ‘Second session of the Ad Hoc Committee’ (Second session of the Ad Hoc Committee to Elaborate a Comprehensive International Convention on Countering the Use of Information and Communications Technologies for Criminal Purposes, 2022) <https: ad_hoc_committee=\"\" chc-second-session.html=\"\" en=\"\" www.unodc.org=\"\"> accessed 1 July 2022; ITU (n 243) Botnet Mitigation Toolkit.\n Plohmann, Gerhards-Padilla, and Leder (n 11) Botnets: Measurement, Detection, Disinfection and Defence 116, 126.\n ibid.</https:></https:>\nREVISITING DUE DILIGENCE IN CYBERSPACE\n\nA final observation is required for the question of the State's capacity to undertake legal and regulatory measures. Some authors have argued that all states are presumably capable of creating such a framework. However, as we highlighted in Factors affecting standard of conduct and Differential capacities for assessment techniques, even creating cybercrime legislation tailored to the threat of Botnet would require financial and technical investments. To reiterate, as of 2020, 27 countries out of 194 surveyed by ITU did not have any cybercrime-specific legislations. Moreover, even if States had cyber-specific legislations, having an adequate regulatory capacity to enforce it could be particularly challenging for LDCs and certain developing states, as discussed earlier.\n## Measures for preventing Botnet infections\nPreventive efforts against Botnets can be much more effective than combating Botnet-related threats once the Botnet mushrooms into harmful scales. If proactive measures are undertaken to this end, the creation of Botnets, and potentially their potency can be limited if and when States deploy Botnet mitigation measures as described in Mitigating or preventing Botnet-related harms. One way to limit the operation and spread of Botnets is to minimize and prevent the infection of devices. There are primarily two methods through which contemporary Botnets can infect devices—first, by exploiting the vulnerabilities in the software, hardware or firmware used by the devices or second, by social engineering.\nThe first method of propagation of malware can be limited first by regulating the suppliers of ICT products in requiring them to follow baseline security measures based on best practices. For this, States such as China, Japan, the United Kingdom, Germany, South Africa and Brazil have focused on technical standards, verification, certification or accreditation schemes. Moreover, similar to the harmonization of criminal provisions, there is a need for inter-State dialogue on global baseline security practice. This is because Botnets frequently infect devices across a tremendous number of States—for instance, the Mirai botnet infected Botnets in around 85 countries. States, particularly LDCs and developing States that do not have the\n ibid. 111.\n Coco, and de Souza Dias (n 30) Cyber due diligence in international law 137.\n Privacy International, 'Guide to International Law and Surveillance' (Privacy International, Dec 2021) <https: 2021%20gils%20version%203.0_0.pdf=\"\" default=\"\" files=\"\" sites=\"\" www.privacyinternational.org=\"\"> accessed 1 July 2022.\n Supra Sub-section on Factors Affecting Standard Of Conduct and Sub-section on Differential Capacities For Assessment Techniques.\n ITU (n 176) Global Cybersecurity Index 2020 vii.\n Supra Sub-section on Differential Capacities For Assessment Techniques.\n Ahmad (n 71) Why Botnets Persist: Designing Effective Technical and Policy Interventions, 26–27; Plohmann, Gerhards-Padilla, and Leder (n 11) Botnets: Measurement, Detection, Disinfection and Defence 123.\n ibid.\n ibid.\n Ahmad (n 71) Why Botnets Persist: Designing Effective Technical and Policy Interventions, 26–27.\n ibid.; Plohmann, Gerhards-Padilla, and Leder (n 11) Botnets: Measurement, Detection, Disinfection and Defence 123; ITU (n 243) Botnet Mitigation Toolkit.\n Coco, and de Souza Dias (n 30) Cyber due diligence in international law 181–186.\n ibid.\n Ahmad (n 71) Why Botnets Persist: Designing Effective Technical and Policy Interventions, 26–27.</https:>\nABHIJEET SHRIVASTAVA AND RUDRAKSH LAKRA\ncapacity to build their own security standards, can benefit from the best practices publicized by international and regional organizations. Further, the vulnerabilities in ICT products can be tackled by carrying out cybersecurity awareness campaigns that focus on end-user awareness to ensure that users keep their software and firmware up to date and install patches. Widespread adoption of baseline security practice could make it exacting for Botmasters to infect secured devices and it would limit the proportion of unsecured devices. Infecting secured devices would require more investment, and if it is more than the expected financial return, the financial incentive for Botmasters to create Botnets at all could be curtailed.\nTurning to the second manner in which Botnets generally propagate—social engineering—it is a method that involves manipulating the end users into committing errors for evading their device security. This is a psychological manipulation technique aiming to manoeuvre users into making security lapses, so as to gain unauthorised access to users' private information, devices, or valuables. However, this method too can be challenged by carrying out cybersecurity awareness campaigns that focus on building tech-literacy, particularly regarding the malware-spreading mechanisms and methods of social engineering. These campaigns should focus more on private companies as end-users, given that they have greater financial resources generally than individual end-users, and particularly small and medium enterprises which are more vulnerable.\nA capacity-building measure that would be common as a defense for both methods of Botnet propagation is conducting extensive cybersecurity awareness programs. These programs require financial bandwidth to fund campaigns, and technical expertise since trained professionals are needed to spearhead them. Comprehensive public cybersecurity campaigns are arduous for developing and LDC countries. For instance, the ITU Cybersecurity Index revealed that more than half of the countries under examination did not have any cybersecurity educational programs or training for professionals. Similarly, a study of cybersecurity awareness for users and executives in Africa found that in the surveyed countries, the lack of such awareness was a major institutional deficiency, necessitating robust programs of this nature.\n## Measures for early detection\nThe obligation of cyber capacity building toward creating a minimum institutional framework also aims at enabling States to detect threats that pose a risk of significant harm. In the case of Botnets, there is a need to create initiatives that focus on their 'early' detection. These can be worked upon by virtue of various mechanisms and initiatives, including some of the presently feasible ones we discuss hereafter. First, Internet Service Providers (ISPs) and DNS\n ITU (n 176) Global Cybersecurity Index 2020 144; Coco, and de Souza Dias (n 30) Cyber due diligence in international law 181–186.\n Ahmad (n 71) Why Botnets Persist: Designing Effective Technical and Policy Interventions, 26–27; Plohmann, Gerhards-Padilla, and Leder (n 11) Botnets: Measurement, Detection, Disinfection and Defence 92–93, 123; ITU (n 176) Global Cybersecurity Index 2020 15–17.\n ibid.\n ibid.\n ITU (n 176) Global Cybersecurity Index 2020 16–17.\n Ahmad (n 71) Why Botnets Persist: Designing Effective Technical and Policy Interventions, 26–27; Plohmann, Gerhards-Padilla, and Leder (n 11) Botnets: Measurement, Detection, Disinfection and Defence 92–93, 123.\n Maria Bada, Angela M. Sasse, Jason R. C. Nurse, 'Cyber Security Awareness Campaigns: Why do they fail to change behaviour?' (International Conference on Cyber Security for Sustainable Society, 9 January 2019) <https: 1901.02672=\"\" abs=\"\" arxiv.org=\"\"> accessed 1 July 2022; Plohmann, Gerhards-Padilla, and Leder (n 11) Botnets: Measurement, Detection, Disinfection and Defence 114, 115.\n ITU (n 176) Global Cybersecurity Index 2020 17–19.\n Maria Bada, Basie von Solms, and Ioannis Agrafiotis, 'Reviewing National Cybersecurity Awareness for Users and Executives in Africa' (2019) 12 International Journal on Advances in Security 108.\n Ahmad (n 71) Why Botnets Persist: Designing Effective Technical and Policy Interventions 27–29; Plohmann, Gerhards-Padilla, and Leder (n 11) Botnets: Measurement, Detection, Disinfection and Defence 72, 123.</https:>\nREVISITING DUE DILIGENCE IN CYBERSPACE\n\n## Collaborative measures\nThroughout the article, we have seen how tackling the threat of Botnets requires cooperation and improved communication between relevant stakeholders since they may hold a distinct piece of the puzzle. As we have previously noted, Botnets are by their very nature transnational in scope, and due to their scale can often only be taken down by the cooperation not only between multiple States but also private parties which are involved in the takedown, such as antivirus companies, researchers, ISP and DNS providers and other tech companies. Impact assessment obligations around Botnets and Mitigating or preventing Botnet-related harms explain how conducting an impact assessment and taking mitigation or prevention measures necessitates a multi-stakeholder approach. A concomitant aim should be to build long-term and sustainable collaborations. Currently, private actors are not always given their due importance and inter-State cooperation on criminal matters is burdensome and slow as shown by contemporary mutual legal assistance processes. Consequently, there is a strong need to create\n Ahmad (n 71) Why Botnets Persist: Designing Effective Technical and Policy Interventions 27–29; Plohmann, Gerhards-Padilla, and Leder (n 11) Botnets: Measurement, Detection, Disinfection and Defence 122.\n Plohmann, Gerhards-Padilla, and Leder (n 11) Botnets: Measurement, Detection, Disinfection and Defence 121.\n ibid. 121, 95–102; Ahmad (n 71) Why Botnets Persist: Designing Effective Technical and Policy Interventions, 32–33.\n Supra Sub-section on Differential Capacities For Assessment Techniques.\n Ahmad (n 71) Why Botnets Persist: Designing Effective Technical and Policy Interventions, 27–29.\n ibid.; Shuang Hao, Nick Feamster, and Ramakant Pandrangi, 'Monitoring the initial DNS behavior of malicious domains' (IMC '11: Proceedings of the 2011 ACM SIGCOMM conference on Internet measurement conference, November 2011) <https: 2011=\"\" conf2011=\"\" docs=\"\" docx=\"\" p269.pdf=\"\" www.nytimes.com=\"\"> accessed 1 July 2022.\n Supra Sub-section on Differential Capacities For Assessment Techniques.\n Plohmann, Gerhards-Padilla, and Leder (n 11) Botnets: Measurement, Detection, Disinfection and Defence 121–23, 126–28.\n For instance, see, David E. Sanger, 'A Botnet Is Taken Down in an Operation by Microsoft, Not the Government' (NY Times, 10 March 2020) <https: 03=\"\" 10=\"\" 2020=\"\" us=\"\" policy=\"\" microsoft-botnets-malware.html=\"\" www.nytimes.com=\"\"> accessed 1 July 2022; Reza Shirazi, 'Botnet Takedown Initiatives: A Taxonomy and Performance Model' (Technology Innovating Management Review, January 2015) <https: 862=\"\" article=\"\" timreview.ca=\"\"> accessed 1 July 2022.\n Supra Sections V and VI.\n Ahmad (n 71) Why Botnets Persist: Designing Effective Technical and Policy Interventions 27–29.\n Jonah Force Hill, 'Problematic Alternatives: MLAT Reform for the Digital Age' 2015 Harvard Law School National Security Journal <https: 01=\"\" 2015=\"\" harvardnsj.org=\"\" problematic-alternatives-mlat-reform-for-the-digital-age=\"\"></https:> accessed 1 July 2022.</https:></https:></https:>\nABHIJEET SHRIVASTAVA AND RUDRAKSH LAKRA\nmuch more streamlined and dedicated channels of communication (both formal and informal), information sharing, and mutual legal assistance between the multitude of actors aforementioned. Cooperation can even be used to facilitate capacity building in the form of sharing of information, and best practices.\n## Review measures\nFinally, as the ILC has noted in their Draft Articles on Transboundary Harm, “[s]tates concerned shall take the necessary...action including the establishment of suitable monitoring mechanisms to implement...” their due diligence obligations. States can first carry out a review that assesses the potential cyber risks, and the landscape of generally foreseeable threats, such as from growing technical developments. This is critical as expectant conduct under the principle of due diligence should evolve with scientific developments. Second, the review should focus on evaluating the progress the State has made regarding the goals it had set for itself in its national or sectoral cybersecurity policies. Third, the review should audit the adequacy of its overall cybersecurity infrastructure and efforts. Lastly, as the ITU recommends, the State can require entities both public and private to carry out an periodic cybersecurity audit that examines the information system’s security. This can focus on the physical configuration of the systems and software, information handling processes, user practices and environment. Again, all these suggestions must be treated as illustrations of good practices crucial for the maximal fruition of States’ due diligence obligations. We do not propose that these exact measures ought to necessarily be pursued as a matter of duty, especially given capacity differentials—however, these presently serve as some of the best possible examples of conduct the diligence of which could not reasonably be doubted. We are, therefore, hopeful for wider adoption of practices of this rigour.\n## CONCLUSION\nThrough this article, we have reaffirmed the increasing confidence in scholarly views for due diligence as a crucial means of regulating transboundary cyber operations. This faith was concretized through a unique legal and policy study of contemporary Botnets, which are among the gravest threats posed in cyberspace. That said, we demonstrated several cautions toward treating due diligence as a panacea against the Pandora’s box of harms opened by the advent of cyberspace, including for Botnets. This included evidentiary dilemmas that target States may face in proving violations of the norm, particularly given the differential standards of conduct expected of States based on their respective capacities—a nuance that we appreciated in relation to the context of the Botnet concerned, as also the State’s capacity against the specific Botnet concerned.\nYet, we also showed that many of these concerns apply to any international legal norm in the face of the novelties of this terrain. Further, due diligence connotes a spectrum of obligations for which target States may pursue the responsibility of a State of origin. This is from the very first stage of demanding that States conduct an impact assessment in the event of a preliminary\n Ahmad (n 71) Why Botnets Persist: Designing Effective Technical and Policy Interventions 27–29.\n Draft Articles on Prevention of Transboundary Harm Article 5.\n Shackelford, Russell and Kuehn (n 84) ‘Unpacking the International Law on Cybersecurity Due Diligence: Lessons from the Public and Private Sectors 41–42.\n Draft Articles on Prevention of Transboundary Harm Article 3 paras [11].\n Shackelford, Russell and Kuehn (n 84) ‘Unpacking the International Law on Cybersecurity Due Diligence: Lessons from the Public and Private Sectors 41–42; ITU (n 176) Global Cybersecurity Index 2020 146.\n ITU (n 176) Global Cybersecurity Index 2020 141.\n ibid.\nREVISITING DUE DILIGENCE IN CYBERSPACE\n\nIn presenting our claims, we have been conscious of the definitional uncertainties that the articulation of due diligence has carried with respect to the 'Corfu Channel' and 'prevention of harm' principles, including in discourse around cyberspace. Yet we argued for a novel coherent conception of due diligence that unifies these principles, providing States and cybersecurity experts much-needed clarity in understanding the scope of its obligations and trigger-thresholds for complex threats such as Botnets. We also outlined various questions with respect to each specific sub-obligation under due diligence that necessitates urgent dialogue between States. In outlining the standards of conduct expected under due diligence, we exposited scientific literature concerning contemporary Botnets, as also several instances of good practices in this context. We are conscious that those illustrations may become anachronistic as technology advances. The point, however, was largely to demonstrate—unlike thus far seen in cyberspace literature—a concrete methodology and guidelines for States to appreciate the precise rigour of diligence that would be required of them against threats like Botnets. To that extent, it is safe to presume that the relevance of these contentions will remain foregrounded for a long time.\nWhile due diligence is indeed a strong legal device to facilitate international co-operation against Botnets, the opposite is equally true. Considering not least the sheer scale of contemporary transboundary Botnets, the fullest and meaningful actualization of due diligence in cyberspace is only possible with greater international co-operation between States and private actors alike, especially for cyber capacity building. Therefore, there remains an urgent need for robust co-operative and consultative efforts against Botnets and similar threats—which in the end, would only be to the collective benefit of the entire international community at large.\n## ACKNOWLEDGEMENT\nThe authors are grateful to Professor Aman for his guidance during their study of cyberspace, and to Professor Sanskriti Sanghi for her feedback and encouragement.",

    "__preamble__": "International Journal of Law and Information Technology, 2022, 30, 321-349\nhttps://doi.org/10.1093/ijlit/eaac021\nAdvance access publication 1 December 2022\nArticle\nOXFORD\n# Revisiting due diligence in cyberspace: crafting international law's arsenal against transboundary Botnets\nAbhijeet Shrivastava* and Rudraksh Lakra*\n# ABSTRACT\nThe emergence of cyberspace has been followed by increasingly unpredictable threats to cybersecurity, including Botnets, which have been frequently exploited in cyber-criminal activities affecting dozens or hundreds of States at once. In existing scholarship, many reasons have informed growing support for the promise of 'due diligence' obligations in regulating transboundary cyber operations. We affirm this position through a study of the specific context of Botnets, although bringing much-needed caution and complexity to the discourse. We offer a comprehensive account of the standard of conduct expected of States in detecting, mitigating and preventing Botnet-linked harms under due diligence; as well as to pursue cyber capacity building toward discharging these obligations. In so doing, we problematize and elaborate on the nature of due diligence as an obligation of conduct, therefore accounting for differential State capacities against Botnet-linked harms. The paper involves attempts to unpack a coherent conception of due diligence, appreciating the spectrum of obligations that it demands, and demonstrating these nuances through an appraisal of good practices adopted by States and private actors against Botnets. Consequently, we provide a unique holistic account of how States and their law enforcement could practically understand the conduct expected of them when faced with transboundary Botnets on a case-to-case basis. In the end, while underscoring potential dilemmas within this legal regime that may be faced by target States, as also its unresolved questions, we submit that due diligence is indeed the most appropriate candidate to act as a legal arsenal against transboundary Botnets.\nKEYWORDS: cyberspace, international law, due diligence, cybersecurity, Botnets.",
    "# INTRODUCTION": "The past decades have witnessed unforeseen and unprecedented technological advancements. The advent of information communication technology (ICT) has birthed a new domain in\n© The Author(s) (2022). Published by Oxford University Press. All rights reserved. For permissions, please email: journals.permissions@oup.com\nABHIJEET SHRIVASTAVA AND RUDRAKSH LAKRA\nhuman society—cyberspace.² Formally defined as an “environment” comprising the “physical and non-physical components” of ICT that transmit data,³ cyberspace is in practice the closest arena one could informally describe as “borderless”.⁴ Yet this terrain brought with it a host of cybersecurity threats, including cybercrime.⁵\nWithin the ecosystem of cybercrime, ‘Botnets’ are the apex species.⁶ Botnets refer to a set of compromised devices (Bots) that are controlled by a ‘Botmaster’ usually without the knowledge of device users, typically to carry out a variety of cybercrimes.⁷ There is “no practical limit” on the number of devices that Botnets may ‘infect’.⁸ For example, the Zeus Botnet has now infected over 13 million devices in 196 countries, causing financial losses of over 120 million USD.⁹ Given the decrease in entry barrier costs in the tool kits required to create Botnets,¹⁰ they are now frequently used for cyber-attacks, distributed denial of service attacks (DDOS), ransomware, click fraud, identity theft, and the spread of hate speech, among other threats.¹¹ Considering their cross-border impact, Botmasters exploit divergences across the domestic legal systems of States to escape accountability.¹² Owing to the vacuum of a globally unified effort against cybercrime, cyber-criminals such as Botmasters seem to enjoy a “safe haven”.¹³\nPresently, there is no major treaty addressing cybercrime, apart from the Convention on Cybercrime (Budapest Convention) which has 66 signatories.¹⁴ Yet even the Budapest Convention has been criticized by many for its narrow set of obligations and its failures to keep up with evolving technology since 2001.¹⁵ As we write, negotiations for drafts of a new treaty on cybercrime are underway under the auspices of the United Nations.¹⁶ However, the scope of this proposed treaty thus far also remains in doubt,¹⁷ and in any case, the extent of its future acceptance would face several obstacles that we discuss hereafter. In summary, there is no effective special law-governing inter-State conduct against cybercrime. Confusion, therefore, prevails as to the legal obligations of States around Botnets and transboundary cyber operations broadly\n² Vasileios Karagiannopoulos, *Living With Hacktivism From Conflict to Symbiosis* (Palgrave Macmillan, 2018) 1–13.\n³ Michael N. The Way Forward for Supporters of an Open, Free, and Secure Internet’ (i, 13 Jan 2022) <https: blog=\"\" new-un-cybercrime-treaty-way-forward-supporters-open-free-and-secure-internet=\"\" www.cfr.org=\"\"> accessed 1 July 2022.\n¹⁶ Walker (n 15) ‘The Quixotic Quest to Tackle Global Cybercrime; Tomaso Falchetta, Deborah Brown and Katitza Rodriguez, ‘Opening Stages in UN Cybercrime Treaty Talks Reflect Human Rights Risks’ (*Just Security*, 18 April 2022) <https: 81105=\"\" opening-stages-in-un-cybercrime-treaty-talks-reflect-human-rights-risks=\"\" www.justsecurity.org=\"\"></https:> accessed 30 June 2022.\n¹⁷ ibid.</https:></https:></https:>\nREVISITING DUE DILIGENCE IN CYBERSPACE\n323\nspeaking.¹⁸ This presents one of the greatest challenges to international law, given not only the increasing number of Botnets; but also, the increasing unilateral action by State actors and private vigilantes against Botnets—which could affect the interests of several other States at once.¹⁹\nIn this context, many scholars have reposed faith in the customary obligation of States to exercise due diligence to prevent transboundary harm to other States (due diligence).²⁰ This is a “best efforts” obligation, which would require States to prevent or minimize harm to other States from Botnets that are being administered under their jurisdiction.²¹ It would equally cover the cyber responses of States or private actors in their jurisdiction against such Botnets with transboundary effects.²² In this article, we affirm this position, albeit while problematizing the unconditional optimism²³ that most authors have shown for due diligence. In The relevance of due diligence for cyberspace, we offer a renewed theoretical formulation of due diligence, which is more precise and clearer than existing scholarship. Simultaneously, we consider why this formulation is appropriate for cyberspace and against Botnets. Since due diligence involves “best effort” obligations, we then dive deep into how the standard of conduct expected from each State would vary based on State cyber capacity differentials and the context of the cyber threat. This analysis in Unpacking differential standards of conduct is accompanied by our reflections on the evidentiary dilemmas that States affected by transboundary harm would face in proving breaches of due diligence.\nThereafter, we categorically elaborate the specific obligations demanded by due diligence in relation to Botnets. Triggers for due diligence obligations discuss the trigger points for the majority of due diligence obligations to become applicable. We then discuss obligations concerning the mitigation and prevention of harm that Botnets may cause to other States as well as the role of international cooperation in this regard. In Impact assessment obligations around Botnets, we analyze the obligation to conduct “impact assessments” in case of a preliminary risk of transboundary harm; and in Mitigating or preventing Botnet-related harms, we proceed to mitigation and prevention obligations, while tracing several instances of State and private-led efforts against various Botnets. Finally, we elaborate the obligation of States toward cyber capacity building against Botnet-like threats in The obligation toward cyber capacity building, with extensive discussion of good practices in that context.     "# THE RELEVANCE OF DUE DILIGENCE FOR CYBERSPACE": "Extensive accounts of the origin and history of due diligence obligations are already present in existing literature²⁴ and will not be reiterated in this Section. Instead, in Reconceiving due diligence, we focus on providing an original and clear theoretical conception of the demands of due diligence. Following this, we briefly discuss in The preference for due diligence the reasons for scholarly confidence in due diligence obligations in the context of cyberspace.",
    "# Reconceiving due diligence": "To what end are due diligence obligations designed? Some scholars have differentiated between two allegedly distinct conceptions of due diligence: first, the 'Corfu Channel principle' as emergent from the earliest judgment of the International Court of Justice²⁵ (ICJ); and second, the 'prevention of harm principle'.²⁶ Turning to the first, the ICJ in Corfu Channel held that Albania violated international law by failing to notify British Ships that Albanian territorial waters contained a minefield.²⁷ This was even though Albania itself was not found responsible for laying the said mines.²⁸ The ICJ also held this to be in breach of the obligation \"not to knowingly allow its territory\" to be \"used for acts contrary to the rights of other States\" [emphasis ours].²⁹ Certain authors consider this to mean that due diligence is a 'standard of conduct' which attaches to \"primary\" norms, including in respecting the \"rights\" of other States.³⁰ For example, in Bosnian genocide, the ICJ held that Serbia and Montenegro violated its duty to prevent genocide in Srebrenica, by failing to exercise \"due diligence\" in using all \"all means reasonably at its disposal\".³¹ In this conception, due diligence does not create self-contained obligations, but only serves as a general rubric to measure compliance with other obligations.³²\nIn parallel, the 'prevention of harm' conception, inter alia, requires States to exercise due diligence so as to prevent or minimize \"significant\" transboundary harm to other States—when such harm originates in their territory.³³ This conception also reflects customary international law, as per the ICJ's judgments in Pulp Mills³⁴ and Nicaragua v. Costa Rica,³⁵ which concerned alleged harms to rivers. In this formulation, due diligence does contain self-contained obligations whenever there is a risk of \"significant\" harm.³⁶ Here, 'significance'\n²⁴ See generally Heike Krieger, Anne Peters, and Leonhard Kreuzer (eds), Due Diligence in the International Legal Order (OUP, 2020).\n²⁵ Coco, and de Souza Dias (n 20) Cyber Due Diligence: A Patchwork of Protective Obligations in International Law.\n²⁶ Corfu Channel (United Kingdom v. Albania) (Merit)  ICJ Rep 4 (Corfu Channel).\n²⁷ Corfu Channel.\n²⁸ Corfu Channel.\n²⁹ Corfu Channel, 22.\n³⁰ Timo Koivurova, 'Due Diligence' (Max Planck Encyclopedias of International Law, Feb 2010) <https: 03=\"\" 2022=\"\" 2022,=\"\" 9780199231690=\"\" 9780199231690-e1034?prd=\"EPIL\" law=\"\" law:epil=\"\" opil.ouplaw.com=\"\" view=\"\"> accessed 1 July 2022, -; Talita Dias &amp; Antonio Coco, 'Cyber due diligence in international law' (Oxford Institute for Ethics, Law and Armed Conflict, 2022) <https: 03=\"\" 2022=\"\" finalreport-bsg-elac-cyberduediligenceininternationallawpdf.pdf=\"\" uploads=\"\" wp-content=\"\" www.elac.ox.ac.uk=\"\"> accessed 1 July 2022, 122.\n³¹ Case Concerning Application of the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide (Bosnia-Herzegovina v. Yugoslavia) (Judgment)  ICJ Rep 2007  (Bosnian Genocide case).\n³² Coco and de Souza Dias (n 30) Cyber due diligence in international law 119; Koivurova (n 30) Due Diligence –; Philip Dalgarno, 'Due Diligence and the Limitations of a Positivist Conception of General Principles of Law' 53 NYU Journal of International Law &amp; Politics 72.\n³³ Draft Articles on Prevention of Transboundary Harm Article 3; Coco and de Souza Dias (n 20) Cyber Due Diligence: A Patchwork of Protective Obligations in International Law 790–794.\n³⁴ Pulp Mills on the River Uruguay (Argentina v. Uruguay), (Merits)  ICJ Rep 4  (Pulp Mills).\n³⁵ Certain Activities Carried out by Nicaragua in the Border Area (Costa Rica v Nicaragua) and Construction of a Road in Costa Rica along the San Juan River (Nicaragua v Costa Rica) (Merits)  ICJ Rep 200 .\n³⁶ Coco and de Souza Dias (n 20) 'Cyber Due Diligence': A Patchwork of Protective Obligations in International Law 790–794.</https:></https:>\nREVISITING DUE DILIGENCE IN CYBERSPACE\n335\ndepends on the scale, context, and magnitude of the harm.³⁷ Scholars argue that this does not require the violation of any primary norm or the recognized rights of other States.³⁸ Rather, the existence of such a risk in se triggers due diligence obligations on a case-to-case basis.³⁹\nIn other words, transboundary activities in the ‘Corfu Channel’ conception require the transboundary activities to be unlawful as such. Under the other, even otherwise unprohibited activities become unlawful when resulting in “significant harm”. What then, is the law as it stands? In their positions on how international law applies to cyberspace, many States have highlighted the Corfu Channel conception,⁴⁰ while others have supported the prevention of harm conception.⁴¹ Some have instead advanced a singular conception where both the violation of a third State’s rights and “significant harm” need to be conjunctively proven.⁴² This is also the approach of the Tallinn Manual 2.0,⁴³ thus far the most authoritative scholarly text on the law applicable to cyberspace.\nWe regret such inconsistent or incomplete formulations of due diligence by States and scholars alike. We argue that both the Corfu Channel principle and the prevention of harm principle must be construed as part and parcel of a singular due diligence norm. In our conception, due diligence requires the prevention of “significant” transboundary harm. First, when such harm is in violation of any international legal obligation, such as the duty to prevent genocide, the harm must be presumed as significant. However, as we elaborate in *Significant harms from Botnets*, only in the rare event that such an illegal act poses only inconsequential harm, due diligence obligations arguably may not be imposed on States of origin if that would cause an undue burden. Second, in the absence of inherent unlawfulness in the transboundary harm, the significance of the harm can then be examined on a case-to-case basis, using factors that we shall elaborate in Triggers for due diligence obligations. This revised conception has many benefits. One, it coheres two strands of due diligence that have both been recognized by the ICJ.⁴⁴ Two, it gives maximal clarity to States seeking to act diligently, as also to States seeking to allege violations of due diligence. Clarity is crucial for any norm to be operational in cyberspace, which is a terrain carrying its own uncertainties.⁴⁵ We therefore adopt this two-fold conception of due diligence in the following Sections.\n³⁷ Certain Activities Carried out by Nicaragua in the Border Area (Costa Rica v Nicaragua) and Construction of a Road in Costa Rica along the San Juan River (Nicaragua v Costa Rica) (Merits)  ICJ Rep 200 .\n³⁸ Coco and de Souza Dias (n 20) ‘Cyber Due Diligence’: A Patchwork of Protective Obligations in International Law, 790.\n³⁹ ibid.\n⁴⁰ Office for Disarmament Affairs, ‘Comments by Member States on the Initial Pre-Draft of the OEWG Report’ (Open-ended Working Group, 2021) <www.un.org disarmament=\"\" open-ended-working-group=\"\"></www.un.org> accessed 1 July 2022 (see individual comments from the Czech Republic and Republic of Korea).\n⁴¹ ‘President of the Republic of Estonia at the opening of CyCon 2019’ (CyCon, 29 May 2019) <https: cjefiles.s3.amazonaws.com=\"\" cgpt=\"\" pdf=\"\" cybernorms=\"\" lawstatements=\"\" remarks+by+the+president+of+the+republic+of+estonia+at+the+opening+of+cycon+2019.pdf=\"\" cech=\"\" cech_rapublic=\"\"> accessed 30 June 2022; Janne Taalas, Ambassador Finland, ‘Statement at the second session of the open-ended Working Group (OEWG) on developments in the field of information and telecommunications in the context of international security’ (Open-ended Working Group, February 2020) <https: 10=\"\" 2018=\"\" ccdcoe.org=\"\" cdc0e=\"\" ccdcoe.org.=\"\" online=\"\" opend=\"\" opend,=\"\" ut=\"\" ut.=\"\" ut.2nd-session-of-oewg.pdf=\"\" uploads=\"\" www.cdci.org=\"\"> accessed 1st July 2022; Organization of American States, ‘Improving Transparency — International Law and State Cyber Operations: Fourth Report (Presented by Prof. Duncan B.     "# The preference for due diligence": "While some have argued that due diligence applies only in the context of international environmental law,⁴⁶ its general coverage finds support in the views of the ICJ,⁴⁷ the International Law Commission (ILC),⁴⁸ and the positions of most States that have discussed how international law applies to cyberspace.⁴⁹ We also take for granted in this article the assertion that all existing international law norms apply to cyberspace, in the absence of new opinio juris to the contrary.⁵⁰ Indeed, this is now the majority view in both scholarship and the recent positions of States.⁵¹ The question then naturally arises as to why for addressing harmful cyber operations, including Botnets, in particular, we choose to focus on due diligence when the entire spectrum of international law remains open.\nSeveral reasons justify this choice. First, consider the frequent situations where the Botnet or cyber operation is conducted by private actors. To prove the responsibility of the State where the transboundary harm originates (State of origin), the State affected by such harm (target State) would have to prove that the Botnet's operation is attributable to the State of origin.⁵² The attribution of private actions, such as this Botnet, would only arise if the stringent factual test of \"instruction, direction or control\" is met.⁵³ The test of \"instruction\" has very limited scope, while the joint test of \"direction or control\" requires proof of \"effective control\" over each allegedly wrongful act.⁵⁴ The latter test has never been successful before the ICJ, and rarely before other fora.⁵⁵ A test that is already onerous is further complicated by the immense difficulties States face in collecting digital evidence of attribution in cyberspace, given, for example, novel masking or spoofing technology.⁵⁶ Therefore, proving the violation of other norms, such as the use of force prohibition, is far from feasible⁵⁷—especially for States lacking advanced cyberinfrastructure.\n⁴⁶ Coco and de Souza Dias (n 20) 'Cyber Due Diligence': A Patchwork of Protective Obligations in International Law, 790.\n⁴⁷ Legality of the Threat or Use of Nuclear Weapons (Advisory Opinion)  ICJ Reps 226 ; Pulp Mills .\n⁴⁸ Draft Articles on Prevention of Transboundary Harm Article 2 , . a.74=\"\" a.75=\"\" a.76=\"\" a.77=\"\" a.78=\"\" a.79=\"\" a.80=\"\" a.81=\"\" a.82=\"\" a.83=\"\" a.84=\"\" a.85=\"\" a.86=\"\" a.87=\"\" a.88=\"\" a.\nREVISITING DUE DILIGENCE IN CYBERSPACE\nWhile some authors raise the continuing debates over the thresholds of other primary norms as another reason to prefer due diligence,58 we do not exaggerate this factor—since as we shall show, concretizing due diligence, including the \"significant\" harm threshold also presents difficulties in cyberspace. Still, due diligence can operate in tandem with those primary norms that contain a preventive or positive effort aspect—such as the positive obligation to prevent genocide,59 protect human rights60 and so forth. In this respect, for failing to take measures against Botnets causing specific kinds of harm, the indirect responsibility of States can be alleged—even when the Botnets are not attributable to the State of origin.61 Furthermore, as we elaborate in Unpacking differential standards of conduct, the conduct expected in due diligence is flexible—responding to the factual context as well as the concerned State's own capacities.62 Therefore, in a terrain such as cyberspace and against the threat of Botnets—both of which are constantly and rapidly evolving, due diligence serves the advantage of accommodating advancements in technology,63 as well as imposing an equitable standard of conduct on the States based on their uneven cyber capabilities.64\nMoreover, as noted in Introduction, there are presently no treaties meaningfully addressing threats such as Botnets. This is, among other reasons, because States have thus far been unwilling to limit their freedoms in ways that may implicate their own policies; as also their hesitations given the unpredictable growths of technology. Yet even if a treaty does arise in the future, we propose that it ought to codify due diligence as aforementioned to operationalize it in cyberspace. Even if it does not, due diligence obligations would co-exist with the treaty obligations, as has been the case previously, unless the treaty provisions conflict with the custom, such that the lex specialis rule is triggered. Finally, as we argue in The obligation toward cyber capacity building, due diligence also imposes a general duty on States toward cyber capacity building, which would enhance cybersecurity worldwide. This capacity building would enable States to detect and mitigate the harms posed by transboundary Botnets, which we elaborate as their obligation in Mitigating or preventing Botnet-related harms. For all these reasons, as international law stands, due diligence is the most appropriate norm for regulating the international response to cyber operations such as Botnets.\n58 Barrie Sander, 'Democracy Under The Influence: Paradigms of State Responsibility for Cyber Influence Operations on Elections' (2019) 18 Chinese Journal of International Law 1, 18-24, 52; Rebecca Crootof, 'International Cyberorts: Expanding State Accountability in Cyberspace' (2018) 103 Cornell Law Review 565.\n59 Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide (adopted 12 January 1951, entered into force 12 January 1951) 78 UNTS 277 Article 1; Application of the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide (Bosnia and Herzegovina v Serbia and Montenegro) (Merits)  ICJ Rep (2007) 43 -.\n60 Koivurova (n 30) Due Diligence, .\n61 Schmitt (n 20) In Defense of Due Diligence in Cyberspace.\n62 Draft Articles on Prevention of Transboundary Harm article 3 , , , , , ; Coco and de Souza Dias (n 20) 'Cyber Due Diligence': A Patchwork of Protective Obligations in International Law 787-88; Buchan (n 20) Cyberspace, Non-State Actors and the Obligation to Prevent Transboundary Harm 443; Bannelier-Christakis (n 20) Cyber Diligence: A Low-Intensity Due Diligence Principle for Low-Intensity Cyber Operations?     "# UNPACKING DIFFERENTIAL STANDARDS OF CONDUCT": "This Section contains one of the most important contributions of this article. It considers an in-depth examination of the implications of due diligence being an obligation of best efforts. First, we discuss a variety of factors to be considered when assessing the standard of conduct expected of States of origin based on their cyber capacity. Simultaneously, we elaborate how the factual context around a concerned cyber threat will affect the State of origin's obligations. Second, we consider if this breath of variable factors may evidently impair a target State's case that a State of origin violated its due diligence obligations. This allows a pragmatic appraisal of the obstacles to establishing State responsibility in inter-State litigation.",
    "# Factors affecting standard of conduct": "The obligation to prevent and minimize significant transboundary harm is an obligation of 'conduct' and not of 'result.' As hinted earlier, this means that due diligence requires a State of origin only to utilize the means reasonably available to it to meet this expectation, rather than succeeding at preventing or minimizing harm. Thus, the obligations imposed on States of origin are commensurate with their wherewithal—i.e., their cybersecurity capacities comprising financial, technical and institutional resources.\nConsider the question of technical means. The most prevalent forms of Botnets involve a 'command and control' server which sends instructions to Bots from specific web domains. One method of disabling a Botnet is \"sinkholing\"—here, law enforcement takes control of these web domains, and redirects the Bot traffic to severs under their control. When the Dutch police took over the Bredolab Botnet in 2010, it employed this method and used its server to notify all affected users that their devices had been compromised. Could one then assume that whenever a Botnet emerges, with the Botmaster operating the command server in The Netherlands, the Dutch police can be presumed to have the means to sinkhole the Botnet? The answer is in negative.\nFor example, several Botmasters have employed techniques to generate mass false domain names, owing to which locating the command server becomes arduous. In such cases, concerns arise as to collisions with legitimate domains when law enforcement attempts to target malicious domains. In addition, as seen in the Mariposa Botnet takedown by Spanish authorities, not all Botnets use \"static malware\", meaning that Botmasters can often update the code of the malware infecting devices so as to prevent detection of the Botnet itself. This is why despite several apparently successful attempts at taking down the Kelihos Botnet, it continued to\n66 Koivurova (n 30) Due Diligence, –.\n69 Draft Articles on Prevention of Transboundary Harm Article 3 , .\n70 For this reason, some authors characterize due diligence as an obligation of 'common but differentiated responsibility' (CBDR). However, we avoid this term given its specific connotation in climate change law – where specific obligations are imposed on legally defined \"developed\" countries to assist the capacity-building of \"developing\" countries. As to capacity-building in cyberspace, see Section on Impact Assessment Obligations Around Botnets. complicate things further, the formats of Botnets keep evolving, with more recent Botnets following a peer-to-peer (P2P) architecture—where a command server is often entirely absent.78 The Dutch sinkholing technique from 2010 could therefore not only be impracticable, but also potentially obsolete depending on the facts of each Botnet. These limited factors suffice to show that at times the very detection of a Botnet may surpass the technical capabilities of a State, let alone a takedown process. Thus, in the absence of knowledge of the Botnet's existence, the obligation to prevent transboundary harm would not even be triggered,79 as we elaborate in Triggers for due diligence obligations.\nWe harp on two points here. First, cybersecurity capacities vary drastically across States.80 The same conduct cannot generally be expected between so-called \"developed\" countries, \"developing\" and \"least developed\" (LDC) countries;81 or even between countries in comparable socio-economic brackets or the same region—given that their cyber capacities against particular threats can differ substantially.82 Second, to reiterate, due diligence requires highly factual assessments.83 Thus, to allege violations of due diligence, target States would have to prove that the concerned State of origin possessed the capacity to detect, mitigate or prevent transboundary Botnet-related harm in relation to the specific Botnet at hand.84\nDespite differences of capacity, some authors argue that there are certain measures for which any State should be presumed as capable—by the very virtue of being a State, such as the creation of legislations to penalize cybercrime.85 However, even the creation of regulations and corresponding enforcement agencies requires financial and technical investments.86 Therefore, the contents, scope and effectiveness of such domestic regimes may vary depending on State capacity, without violating due diligence. Therefore, one must be cautious when asserting any supposedly universal expectations under due diligence. At the same time, as State capacity advances, the standard of diligent conduct would also advance commensurably.87 Hence, if a State previously lacking cybercrime police, Botnet detection or mitigation techniques later\n77 Arsh Arora, 'Kelihos Botnet: A Never-Ending Saga' (Annual ADFSL Conference on Digital Forensics, Security and Law, 2017). <https: commons.erau.edu=\"\" cgi=\"\" cgi?viewcontent.cgi?article=\"1271&amp;context=adfsl\"> accessed 1 July 2022 9.\n78 Ahmad (n 71) Why Botnets Persist: Designing Effective Technical and Policy Interventions 9.\n79 Draft Articles on Prevention of Transboundary Harm Article 3 para  and ; Coco and de Souza Dias (n 20) 'Cyber Due Diligence': A Patchwork of Protective Obligations in International Law, 793–94.\n80 International Telecommunications Union, Global Cybersecurity Index 2020 Measuring commitment to cybersecurity (ITU Publications 2020); Andrea Calderaro and Anthony J. Yet one is compelled to wonder if the evidentiary burden of a State to prove these variable factors may become self-defeating, negating the promising potential of due diligence in establishing State responsibility.\n## Evidentiary concerns\nIn proving the aforementioned facts, three considerations must be examined separately: the 'burden', 'method' and 'standard' of proof.⁸⁸ The burden of proof concerns whether certain facts must be proven by a particular party—as per the ICJ, the party alleging due diligence violations must prove the necessary facts.⁸⁹ The method of proving facts can either comprise direct or indirect evidence. In Nicaragua v. Costa Rica, the ICJ showed preference for direct scientific evidence, at least on the question of whether the harm alleged over the San Huan river was \"significant\".⁹⁰ Yet in Corfu Channel, the ICJ allowed \"liberal recourse\" to inferences from indirect (circumstantial) evidence proving Albania's knowledge of the placing of mines on its territory.⁹¹ This was because any direct evidence would have been in Albania's exclusive control.⁹² Analogizing, some authors argue that States litigating against cyber operations would face similar evidentiary obstacles, and thus, courts should be amenable to circumstantial digital evidence.⁹³\nHowever, even so, in Corfu Channel, the ICJ only found for the United Kingdom since its set of indirect evidence left \"no room for reasonable doubt\".⁹⁴ This is the 'standard' of proof—i.e., the extent to which the Court must be persuaded as to the existence of facts.⁹⁵ In later cases where the opposing State's direct evidence contradicted the available circumstantial evidence, this standard was not met for the ICJ.⁹⁶ This, in effect means that if States of origin are able to provide direct evidence contradicting the indirect evidence of target States on any count, the latter's case would likely fall. Crucially moreover, in Bosnian Genocide, the Court held that it would apply a higher standard of proof for charges of \"exceptional gravity\"—in that case, concerning the genocide prohibition.⁹⁷ With regard to proving due diligence allegations on factual significant harm in se, the Court has not indicated a precise standard of proof.⁹⁸ Yet at least for cases where applicant States found their submissions on due diligence as a measure of compliance for primary norms, the standards of proof may shift based on the \"gravity\" of the allegations.⁹⁹\nFinally, it should be acknowledged that the ICJ in Pulp Mills was asked by Argentina to grant similar flexibilities as in Corfu Channel; although the Court found no need to inquire into the request since it did not consider Argentina evidentially disadvantaged.¹⁰⁰ Moreover, to reiterate,\n⁸⁸ Michael P. Scharf and Margaux Day, 'The International Court of Justice's Treatment of Circumstantial Evidence and Adverse inferences' (2012) 13 Chicago Journal of International Law 123, 129; Sharngan Aravindakshan, 'Cyberattacks: a look at evidentiary thresholds in International Law' (2020) 59 Indian Journal of International Law, 285.\n⁸⁹ Pulp Mills .\n⁹⁰ Certain Activities Carried out by Nicaragua in the Border Area (Costa Rica v Nicaragua) and Construction of a Road in Costa Rica along the San Juan River (Nicaragua v Costa Rica) (Merits)  ICJ Rep 200 .\n⁹¹ Corfu Channel.\n⁹² ibid.\n⁹³ Aravindakshan (n 88) Cyberattacks: a look at evidentiary thresholds in International Law 285.\n⁹⁴ Corfu Channel.\n⁹⁵ Aniruddha Rajput, 'Standard of Proof' (Max Planck Encyclopedias of International Law, February 2021) <https: 10.1093=\"\" lea-mpeipro=\"\" opil.ouplaw.com=\"\" view=\"\" view=\"\"> accessed 1 July 2022 .\n⁹⁶ Michael P. Scharf and Margaux Day, 'The International Court of Justice's Treatment of Circumstantial Evidence and Adverse inferences' (2012) 13 Chicago Journal of International Law 123, 141.\n⁹⁷ Bosnian Genocide case .\n⁹⁸ While it has used the phrases \"clear\", \"sufficient\" or \"convincing\" evidence sporadically, the import of these terms was never clarified. See Pulp Mills , , , , ; Certain Activities Carried out by Nicaragua in the Border Area (Costa Rica v Nicaragua) and Construction of a Road in Costa Rica along the San Juan River (Nicaragua v Costa Rica) (Merits)  ICJ Rep . , .\n⁹⁹ It is arguable that, inter alia, allegations regarding the positive duties to protect human rights and to ensure respect for humanitarian law would also be considered \"grave\" depending on the facts of the case, see D W Greig, 'The Underlying Principles of International Humanitarian Law' (1980) 9 Australian Year book of International Law 46; Johannes Morsink, 'World War Two and the Universal Declaration' (1993) 15 Human Rights Quarterly 357.\n¹⁰⁰ Pulp Mills .</https:>\nREVISITING DUE DILIGENCE IN CYBERSPACE\n331\nCorfu Channel did not concern the factual \"significant harm\" conception of due diligence, which arguably carries higher evidentiary scrutiny given its demands of scientific evidence.¹⁰¹ Thus, it remains open for States to argue that the standard of proof should be relaxed in case of States facing Botnet-related factual \"significant\" harms (when they are evidentially disadvantaged). It appears unlikely, however, that the Court would depart from its previous approaches.¹⁰²\nConsidering all this, and in light of the differential facts to be proven for asserting a specific standard of conduct as per the previous Sub-Section, one may be inclined to conclude that proving due diligence violations is in fact more difficult than for other norms—contrary to our view in The relevance of due diligence for cyberspace. While these challenges are certainly formidable, we hesitate to dismiss our preference for due diligence. First, the high standard of proof applied to presentations of circumstantial evidence would affect submissions on any norm violation in cyberspace, not just due diligence.¹⁰³ This would include attempts to attribute private actions to States of origin, the tests for which are in any case extremely stringent.¹⁰⁴ Accordingly and second, due diligence would help avoid impunity by facilitating indirect responsibility at least in certain cases.¹⁰⁵ This is especially for cases where the State of origin manifestly takes none or negligible efforts against the private group¹⁰⁶—i.e., it enabled the Botnet's administration by its unwillingness to act for whatever reason.\nTo reiterate, it could be difficult to prove violations of due diligence expectations that heavily hinge on State capacity (such as Botnet takedowns).¹⁰⁷ Perhaps, even proving the \"risk\" of \"significant\" harm could pose difficulties, as we discuss in Triggers for due diligence obligations. Nevertheless, there would be recourse at least when States of origin attempt unilateral measures against Botnets that could have potential impacts on other States. The target State could argue that a prior \"impact assessment\" should necessarily be held—so as to examine if \"significant\" harm may result from the measure.¹⁰⁸ Indeed, in Nicaragua v. Costa Rica, the ICJ found that Costa Rica violated this procedural requirement, even though it also considered that there was no risk of significant harm at the time.¹⁰⁹ As we elaborate in Impact Assessment Obligations Around Botnets, it is arguable that in conducting such impact assessments, the potentially affected States must be consulted, thus maximizing inter-State cooperation. In any case, when a risk of significant harm is found, the obligation to notify and co-operate with the other States would be triggered.¹¹⁰ Albania's omission to respect this very obligation was what entitled the United Kingdom for full compensation for the damage inflicted on its warships.¹¹¹ Therefore,\n¹⁰¹ Alan Boyle, 'Developments in the International Law of Environmental Impact Assessments and their Relation to the Espoo Convention' (2011) 20 Review of European Community &amp; International Environmental Law, 227.\n¹⁰² Application of the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide (Croatia v.
